title: Ireland–Scotland Professional Match
text:
The Ireland–Scotland Professional Match was an annual men's professional <a href="golf">golf</a> competition between teams representing <a href="Ireland">Ireland</a> and <a href="Scotland">Scotland</a>. It was played from 1932 to 1936. The match was played on a single day with 10 players in each team who played 5 foursomes and 10 singles matches. The first match in 1932 was tied but Ireland won the next four contests.
History.
The two countries played a match on 18 May 1907, just before the <a href="Irish%20PGA%20Championship">Irish Professional Championship</a>. On that occasion the Scottish team was weak and Ireland won by 13 matches to 4.
The 1932 match was played as a match between the Irish and Scottish PGA Associations which meant that <a href="Mark%20Seymour%20%28golfer%29">Mark Seymour</a>, an Englishman, played for Scotland, where he was resident, and <a href="Sydney%20Fairweather">Sydney Fairweather</a>, a Scot who was the professional at <a href="Malone%20Golf%20Club">Malone Golf Club</a>, played for Ireland.
In 1937 the two countries played each other during the <a href="Triangular%20Professional%20Tournament">Triangular Professional Tournament</a> while in 1938 they met as part of the <a href="Llandudno%20International%20Golf%20Trophy">Llandudno International Golf Trophy</a>. The 1937 and 1938 matches were both won by Scotland.
Appearances.
The following are those who played in at least one of the five matches. <a href="Sydney%20Fairweather">Sydney Fairweather</a> played for Scotland in the <a href="England%E2%80%93Scotland%20Professional%20Match">England–Scotland Professional Match</a> in 1933, 1935, 1936 and in the <a href="Llandudno%20International%20Golf%20Trophy">Llandudno International Golf Trophy</a> in 1938. <a href="Mark%20Seymour%20%28golfer%29">Mark Seymour</a> played for England in the England–Scotland Professional Match in 1932 and 1933.
